title: Which party will hold a majority in the US Senate after the 2018 midterm elections?
possible_answers: Democratic Party, with 53 senators or more
Democratic Party, with less than 53 senators
Republican party, with less than 53 senators
Republican Party, with 53 senators or more
correct_answer: Republican Party, with 53 senators or more

My guess right now, based on polling averages, is Republicans 52 seats, Democrats 48 seats.

I believe the Republicans only need to win 9/35 seats to maintain their majority, by my math, they already fairly securely have eight seats. The Democrats, on the other hand, fairly securely have 21/35 seats, leaving six seats in contention. Of those six seats, two are leaning towards the Democrats with a slight bit of safety, while four are too close to call with any degree of certainty, but three lean towards Democrats. Mathematically, assuming my forecasts are correct, the Democrats can't win. At best they can split the Senate 50/50, but the first two options say Democrats win.  That leaves the last two options.  5/6 seats in contention lean Democrat, with Missouri being split right down the middle. In order to get to 53+ Senators, the Republicans would need to win three of the six seats, none of which are in States where they have polled more favourably than the Democrats.

According to RCP and Sabato Crystal Ball, there are 6 or 5, respectively) tossup races. Many races have moved from Tossup to Republican column, and some leaning Democrats moved to toss up. There are 50 leaning or likely republicans, making it hard to put any real chance for Democrats to take control of the Senate. Even when they won all 6 tossups, the Pence tie-breaker will still keep Republicans in control. So, is it 52 or less republicans (50,51,52) or 53 or more (53, 54,55,56)?

I started reading fivethirtyeight after a hiatus that started in November of 2016.  https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/senate/?ex_cid=rrpromo

Time to put some comments down:
 - generally, these elections look like they would push further the polarization trend: red states will tend to elect more Rs, blue states - more Dems, with the only real fight in the purple states. This bodes well for Rs.  - an intriguing (for forecasters) tendency is that the Senate elections will be entirely dominated by the inside view (what is happening on the ground in each race) as opposed to the outside view (what has happened previously in similar situations). Specifically, Rs seem well positioned to keep or even add to their Senate seats even though the nation-wide popular vote swings against them. This seems to be the result of two inside characteristics: (i) the Senate electoral map in 2018, and (ii) the rural vs. urban aspect of the political polarization, which helps Rs in the Senate and Dems in the House.     - as for my specific choices, I now give ND and TN to the Rs. I maintain my previous calls that TX remains an R seat, while WV and MT - Dems' (although Tester does not look invincible in MT). This leaves five toss-ups: AZ, NV, IN, MO, and FL. For these, I use the average probability between Nate Silver's shop (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/senate/?ex_cid=rrpromo) and predictit (https://www.predictit.org/markets/1/US-Elections?filterIds=1,5&sort=traded&sortParameter=ALL). Silver still seems to lean toward higher Dems chances, while predictit customers have turned quite a bit toward Rs recently. So the average between the two more or less reflects the high uncertainty in these races.

An update, using the latest data and reducing somewhat the level of discretion in my earlier forecasts: 1. The largest number of toss-up states I have seen is 10: AZ, NV, IN, MO, ND, FL, TN, WV, TX and MT (https://www.270towin.com/2018-senate-election/sabatos-crystal-ball-2018-senate-ratings) 2. Out of these 10, I assign three to their incumbents (WV, TX, MT) based on two criteria:
 - the average of recent polls produces a lead greater than 4 percentage points (broadly the poll's average margin of error) -  see https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2018/senate/2018_elections_senate_map.html;  - the probabilities at predictit.com (https://www.predictit.org/Browse/Group/54/Senate) are above 60%.  3. I also assign IN to its incumbent Donnelly. His lead in the polls is a solid 5.7%, and at the latest poll (late August) he led by 6%. This is admittedly a sleight-of-hand, as predictit.com gives him only 52%, but I think the former factors weigh more. 4. This leaves 6 "true" toss-ups: AZ, NV, ND, MO, FL, and TN. Note that before considering those, Rs have 48 seats and Ds - 46.  5. Now to get to a majority (51), Ds have to win at least 5 of these 6 seats. Using the probabilities from predictit.com and assuming the races are independent (my second and slightly more serious sleight-of-hand), I come with a probability of 9% for the Ds to do so.  5. Similarly, For Rs to get at least 53 seats, they need to win at least 5 of these 6 races. This works out to about 13%.     

6. Finally, what is left for the largest bucket (Rs keep the majority with less than 53 seats) is 100-9-13=78

Adjusting the chances of a Republican net pickup of two or more seats upward. I think roughly as likely as Democrats retaking the Senate. Still, I think the most likely outcome is a narrow Republican majority close to the current margin.

An update just before the campaign starts in earnest:  Nine toss-up states: AZ, FL, IN, MO, MT, ND, NV, TN, TX (now that's a surprise) - Looks like the Dems will win AZ and IN (see the polls); I am also giving them NV despite the tight polls - Dems' mobilization will likely be stronger there;  - I assign FL and TN to the Republicans (In FL Scott is building a steady lead, while in TN it would be too much to expect a Democrat to win, notwithstanding the personalities involved). TX should also go to the Rs (it would take an earthquake to dislodge Cruz) - This practically eliminates the possibility that the Dems gain majority. Even if they win all 3 of the remaining states (MO, MT, ND), this only brings them to 50/50. I'll keep a 2 percent probability, though, in case I am wrong about the above assumptions.  - Now: to get to 53 seats, the Republicans will have to win all three of MO, MT, and ND. This looks difficult. Still, using the probabilities from predictit.com results in a 12% probability for Rs winning all 3. I am adding 2% more in case I am wrong about AZ, NV, or IN (predictit bettors are pessimistic about Dems' chances in AZ and IN) - This leaves 84% for the middle bucket (Rs in the majority with less than 53 seats)
All things being equal, I think Democrats would win handily, but the specific seats up for reelection are not in their favor.

Jim Ellis is a 35-year political veteran who now analyzes election data for major corporations, associations, and legislative advocacy firms. He is president of Ellis Insight, LLC. We invited him to share analysis of primary turnout. At this point in the 2018 election cycle, 37 states have held primary elections and so far the actual voting patterns may be contradicting some prognosticators and pollsters’ common wisdom. Most in the aforementioned group are predicting that Democratic voter enthusiasm is such that a "blue wave" could form. But when looking at who is actually turning out in the 2018 elections, a more typical midterm participation pattern exists. More Republicans than Democrats are voting in states that tend to support GOP candidates, and more Democrats than Republicans are coming to the polls in places where the former party’s candidates typically win the preponderance of elections. In the south and Rocky Mountain region, and pertaining to certain Midwest states, more Republicans are voting. In the east, Pacific Northwest, and a different Midwest domain subset more Democrats are voting. But, there are reasons to delve deeper within those numbers. In California, while Democrats turned out in greater numbers for the statewide jungle primary in early June, more Republicans voted in six of the seven congressional districts where Democrats are targeting as must-win elections. Turning to Pennsylvania, where Democrats have more than an 800,000-person statewide voter registration advantage, the party turnout figure exceeded Republican participation by only about 15,000 individuals. Looking at New York, where upstart candidate Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez knocked ten-term Rep. Joe Crowley (D) from the Democratic ballot and forcing him to only appear on the Working Families Party line in the general election, only 27,658 people voted, allowing the challenger to win with under 16,000 votes. Statewide, in 13 Democratic congressional primaries, the party averaged a turnout percentage of just over 11 percent. Yet in two states that have been consistently voting Republican since the turn of the century, West Virginia and Kentucky, more Democrats voted in those state primaries. Thus, we are seeing some examples of juxtaposition within the electorate, which makes predicting the fall results even more difficult. Primary turnout does not ultimately predict general election participation figures or results, but it does provide an idea of how the electorate is responding. While news reports, generic polls, certain presidential approval ratings, and some more local special election results suggest 2018 will be a more Democratic year than in recent past midterm elections, actual voter participation in two-thirds of the states already holding primary elections appear to be foretelling a different story.

Update:
 - Eight toss-up states:  AZ, FL, IN, MO, ND, NV, TN, WV(https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2018/senate/2018_elections_senate_map.html) - Simplifyng assumptions: Dems win AZ and WV, R's win TN (according to the polls). Also giving NV to the Dems (the polls are tight, but the bets on predictit.com are heavily for the Dems).  - To win a majority (51), Dems have to win all 4 of the remaining states (FL, IN, MO, ND). This looks extremely difficult. Using the probabilities from predictit.com results in a 5% probability for Dems winning all 4, but I think this is an overstatement. Surely the Rs will spare no effort to elect a Republican in Indiana, the state of VP Pence. So I am going to reduce this down to 2% (not zero just on the basis that anything can happen).  - On the other hand, to get to 53 seats, the Rs have to win all four (FL, IN, MO, ND). This also looks unlikely, although less so than for the Dems to win all these seats. Predictit.com suggests a probability of 8%. I am going to increase this to 16% on the ground that NV and AZ may turn out to be in play as well.   - This leaves 82% for the middle bucket (Rs in the majority with less than 53 seats)

The reasons that make it so difficult for the Democrats to win the Senate are unchanged: they have to defend 26 seats while the Republicans just a third (9) of that number. Even if all the 26 Democratic seats were safe (which they are not), they would still need to take 2 seats from the 9 Republican incumbents. The Democrat's biggest opportunities are in Arizona and Nevada. In Arizona we will have to wait until the Republican primary on August 28th to see who will be running on the Republican side. In Nevada, the most recent polls show that Heller and Rosen have the same support and the rating Toss-up is correct. There are at the moment no signs that these states move significantly towards the Democrats.
Simulations, based on the ratings by Cook, Sabato and Inside Elections (Safe=95%, Likely=85%, Lean=75%, Tilt+Toss up=50%) give a mean of 24 seats for the Democrats (a loss of 2), and a probability smaller than 1% of getting 28 seats or more. I just cannot find something that could point into the direction of a Democratic win.

Since my last forecast we have gotten much more data on the senate races so its definitely time to look at the questions again. Current breakdown is 51-49 for the republicans (counting the two independents as democrats for simplicity). Republicans defend 8 seats while democrats defend 25. Democrats have 3 good pickup opportunities (Arizona, Nevada, and Tennessee). Republicans have pickup chances in Florida, Indiana, and North Dakota where they are leading in polls, and in Missouri and West Virginia where they aren't. Polling in most races is still pretty sparse (Missouri polling is two months old and there's been one poll in North Dakota in the last five months) so I expect to keep updating as we get more data.
Not much confidence here. A lot can change between now and November.

Current Senate map shows Dems hold 44 seats (either safe or leaning Dem), GOP 48 and 8 tossup. That means GOP needs to get 2 out of 8 tossup seats to retain control of Senate (50 + VP Pence tie-breaker) and 5 out of 8 to get 53 or more. Democrats are very vulnerable in 3 states: MO, ND and FL.  It is harder to ascertain if GOP could get to the 53 threshold.  In order for Dems to get to 53, they need to get all the 8 tossup plus 1 "leaning". While Cruz is "leaning" in TX, I don't believe TX will turn purple any time soon. Therefore, there is 0 chance Dems would get over 53.  Dems may still get the majority of 51 by gaining 7 out of 8 tossup seats.

The only way I see the Democrats getting 53 is by flipping Nevada (https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2018/senate/nv/nevada_senate_heller_vs_rosen-6304.html) and Texas (https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2018/senate/tx/texas_senate_cruz_vs_orourke-6310.html), and winning both the Arizona (can't give a RealClear link b/c primaries haven't finished) senate race and the Tennessee senate race (https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2018/senate/tn/tennessee_senate_blackburn_vs_bredesen-6308.html) The only one that doesn't seem very possible is the Texas race. However, RealClear says it's "one to watch". Summary: +5 for Dem 53+

Slight adjustment to forecast (small decrease to Dem. chances for now), based upon the following interesting analysis (ref. link) -- also posted by 'Annieinak', below. https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/democrats-horrible-2018-senate-map-couldnt-have-come-at-a-better-time/

https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/democrats-horrible-2018-senate-map-couldnt-have-come-at-a-better-time/ MAY 1, 2018 
. . . 
. . .  while the 2018 map is the party’s steepest uphill climb in a long time, defending red-state Senate seats isn’t a new challenge for Democrats. In fact, they’ve gotten pretty good at it over the years. . . .  the Senate . . . has an inherent Republican bias . . .  To quantify how well Democrats have overcome this handicap in the past . . .  At least since 1992, . . . Democrats have regularly faced unfavorable Senate maps (albeit none as bad as 2018’s), and they have regularly overperformed anyway, winning an average of 2.4 more seats per cycle than they are entitled to based on partisan lean alone. Much of this is likely because of the advantage of incumbency, but on three occasions (1992, 2006 and 2012), Democrats have actually gained Senate seats despite being at a partisan-lean disadvantage.5 Only in three famously strong GOP wave years (1994, 2010 and 2014) have Republicans overperformed the partisan baseline. The good news for Senate Democrats is that, given the party’s healthy lead in generic-ballot polling, they are likely to overperform again this year. The bad news is that overperforming by enough to take back control would be unprecedented (at least in modern history). . . .  Democrats need to overperform by a whopping 11 seats in order to snag a majority. Still, Democrats should probably be thrilled with an overperformance of even half that. . . .  In short, 2018 could be not just bad, but a veritable armaggeddon for Senate Democrats. They should count their lucky stars that their worst-case map looks like it’s going to coincide with their best-case turnout environment. The Senate isn’t just biased toward Republicans; it’s really biased toward Republicans. Going by partisan lean, there are 31 states more Republican-leaning than the nation as a whole compared with just 19 states more Democratic-leaning. Because each state has two senators, that means 62 Senate seats (a filibuster-proof supermajority) are Republican-leaning and 38 are Democratic-leaning. But thanks to the Democratic overperformance we’ve been talking about, Republicans hold only a 51-49 majority. Democrats have achieved this by electing a total of 14 senators in red states while holding Republicans to only three senators in blue states. . . .  That’s a glaring Achilles heel for Democrats. One bad election cycle for this class could virtually eliminate red-state Democrats from the Senate in one fell swoop. That would give Republicans something like a 20-seat majority in the upper chamber — probably too wide for Democrats to overcome in any single future election cycle. . . .  a bad 2018 could condemn Democrats to the Senate minority indefinitely — at least until something big changes about American political parties.

Rep. Luke Messer (R-Ind.) released a new ad in the Republican primary for U.S. Senate in Indiana criticizing state Rep. Mike Braun (R)'s voting record as a Democrat. Standing in front of a cardboard cutout of Braun, Messer says in the ad, "Braun was a Democrat, even during the Obama years. ... I am who I say I am. I'm conservative. I support the president."
Braun voted in Democratic primaries for more than a decade, according to Dubois County records from 1996 through 2008, and a Republican National Committee voter database labeled Braun a "Hard Democrat." Braun voted in a Republican primary in 2012 and ran as a Republican for the state legislature in 2014.
Braun spokesman Josh Kelley said in December, "As is often the case in solidly blue counties, like Dubois was at the time, Mike cast his vote in competitive local primaries where it would have the greatest impact, while voting solidly Republican in general elections."
President Trump endorsed U.S. Rep. Jim Renacci (R) ahead of the May 8 Republican Senate primary. Renacci and businessman Mike Gibbons are vying for the GOP nod to take on incumbent Sherrod Brown (D) in the November general election. Brown is one of 10 Senate Democrats facing re-election in a state Trump won in 2016.
Trump tweeted his endorsement of Renacci, citing his support for Trump’s preferred policies on taxes, immigration, and crime. Trump previously appeared at a rally for Renacci in February, and Vice President Mike Pence attended a forum with him in March.
Renacci had been running in Ohio’s gubernatorial election, but he dropped out to run for Senate in January 2018 after State Treasurer Josh Mandel, who lost to Brown in 2012, withdrew from the race. Renacci said that the Trump administration convinced him to make the change.
Renacci is favored to win the Republican primary. He was endorsed by Mandel, U.S. Sen. Rob Portman (R-Oh.), and all Republican members of the state’s U.S. House delegation. Election forecasters give Brown a slight edge in the general election, rating the seat as “Leans Democratic.”
Former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn is hitting the campaign trail for businessman Troy Downing in Montana’s U.S. Senate Republican primary. Downing’s campaign announced that Flynn would join him on April 24.
Downing is in a four-way race to see who will take on incumbent Jon Tester (D) in November. Although he leads the race in fundraising due to his self funding, he has trailed State Auditor Matt Rosendale and former Judge Russ Fagg in recent polls. Tester is one of 10 Senate Democrats running for re-election in a state Donald Trump won in the 2016 presidential election.
Flynn served as national security advisor from January to February 2017, resigning following reports that he did not provide Vice President Mike Pence with accurate information about a conversation that he had with a Russian ambassador concerning sanctions against the country. Prior to serving in the Trump administration, he worked on Trump’s presidential campaign and on his presidential transition team.
In December 2017, Flynn pled guilty to making false statements to the FBI about his conversations with the ambassador. He agreed to cooperate with Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election as part of his plea deal.
April 24 was the filing deadline for candidates running in the U.S. Senate special election in Mississippi. The election will be a nonpartisan race on November 6, 2018, with a runoff on November 27, 2018, if no candidate receives a majority of the vote in the general election. The winner will replace Thad Cochran (R), who announced on March 5, 2018, that he would resign his seat on April 1, 2018, due to health concerns. Cindy Hyde-Smith was appointed by Gov. Phil Bryant (R) to fill the vacancy on March 21, 2018.
Hyde-Smith is running for election to the seat along with four others: former U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Mike Espy (D), Mayor of Tupelo Jason Shelton (D), Mississippi State Senator Chris McDaniel (R), and Tobey Bartee.
Candidates running for certain races in Florida must file by noon on May 4. Candidates will be filing for U.S. Senate, U.S. House, judicial offices, state attorney, and public defender. Candidates running for a state executive office, state legislative seat, or a county seat have until June 22 to file. Aside from those races, Florida has the 35th statewide filing deadline in 2018.
In the U.S. Senate race, Senator Bill Nelson (D) is seeking re-election. There are also elections for Florida’s 27 members of the U.S. House of Representatives. Florida is currently represented by 11 Democrats and 16 Republicans.

The Senate picture is getting more complicated. In my view, now there are six states in play: AZ, IN, MO, ND, TN, and FL (I assume that the Dems will gain Nevada and hold elsewhere). Among the six, the Dems currently hold IN, MO, ND, and FL, while the Rs hold AZ and TN). Possible outcomes (taking individual state probabilities from predictit.com and assuming the races are largely independent of each other (they are not, but the resulting error is probably modest):
 - Dems win all 6. This will bring them to 52 seats, as I assume they will also get Nevada. Probability: 3%
 - Dems win any 5. This gives them 51 seats. Probability: 15%
 - Dems win any 4, getting 50 seats. This keeps Rs in control
 - Dems win any 3, for 49 seats. Ditto
 - Dems win any 2, for 48 seats. Rs have 52.
 - Dems win only 1 seat, giving Rs 53.  Probability: 5.2% 
 - Dems win zero seats out of these six, letting the Rs with 54 seats.  Probability: 0.6%.  So the first two outcomes form the 18% probability for Dems to gain control of the Senate, while the last two produce the probability of Rs getting more than 53 seats. The rest goes to the middle bucket.

There are 9 battleground states, 7 of which are Democratic held and 2 of which are GOP held. There are 33 seats in play, 25 of which are Democrat held and 8 of which are GOP. The more you dig into the math, the worse it looks for the Democrats. There are more seats held by Democrats in states that Trump won, there are more seats held by Democrats in states with GOP governors. Even if the Democrats won their battles for seats in play in battleground states, they would have to successfully defend many seats. This makes it more likely that the GOP will actually pick up seats, than that they will lose control of the Senate. In my view, it makes it at least as likely that they will end up with more than 53 seats than have the majority with less than 53. The factors that favor the Democrats are all subjective and harder to measure. Greater mobilization of the Democratic base, anger with Trump, Trump's poor approval ratings, anger at mass shootings, Trump putting his foot in his mouth, the tax cut (which seems to be relatively well-received) - these are subjective factors that could play a large role in what happens. Since most of the subjective factors seem to favor the Democrats, we'll give a significant but lower likelihood that the Democrats retake the Senate.
With few Republicans up for reelection in purple states, this is probably going to be a squeaker.  But I think the Senate will end up with 51 Democrats and Independents.

Again, I'm going for consistency with my forecast in the related question on the Global Judgment Challenge. If the Dems take the Senate, it will be by a narrow margin because the deck is stacked against them (so many seats to defend, so few opportunities to pick up Republican seats). I do expect the outcome to be very close, however, and am assigning only a 5% probability to a Republican majority of 53 seats or more.

Reviewing my analysis from yesterday (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/697829), it now appears to me that I have underestimated the chance of Rs getting to 53 or more Senate seats. In addition to the four toss-up races (AZ/MO/IN/ND), other possible D hick-ups (e.g., FL, WV, or the open seat in MN) would tend to raise the chance of a 53+ seat R majority, while the 6 remaining races with R incumbents appear quite safe for the GOP for now. I still think the probability mass is concentrated in the Rs getting 50-52 seats, though.
Koch brothers are putting $400 million themselves to buy the election and there are 24 Democratic seats up vs 8 Republican seats.

Unlikely for the GOP to pick up more than 2 seats, even though they have a highly favourable map. At the same time this makes it unlikely for the Dems to pick up a significant number of seats. Rather strong tails due to the possibility of a wave. 
Suppose that Trump does something truly shocking (which I don't really know what it could be) I can imagine a number of seats going over to Dems. If nothing special happens Reps should hold a slight lead.

First, some basic assumptions:
 - 34 seats are up, 26 currently held by Ds and D-leaning independents, 8 by Rs.
 - I assume only 4 races are competitive: AZ (currently held by a Republican), MO, IN, ND (held by Ds).
 - I also assume that Ds gain Nevada (the incumbent Heller is given only a 30% chance of winning by predictit.com) Note that these assumptions favor the Ds: they ignore Nelson's vulnerability in FL (if Governor Scott decides to run against him) and Joe Manchin's not-that-comfortable position in WV. More on all this below.  Possible outcomes from the 4 toss-ups:
 - Rs win all 4. Currently Predictit.com puts this chance at 4% (assuming all 4 races are independent, which they may not be, but the resulting error is likely to be modest). This will bring them to 53 seats (as they already hold AZ and have lost Nevada per my assumption).
 - Rs win any three. A little arithmetics shows that Predictit customers estimate this probability at 21% (see https://www.predictit.org/Browse/Group/54/Senate). It may go slightly higher if AZ gets more competitive. This will bring Rs to 52 seats. 
 - Rs and Ds win 2 seats apiece. This is worth about 37% now and will keep Rs at 51 seats. 
 - Rs win 1 seat out of these 4. Probability: 30% Seats: 50 (still a majority as VP Pence gets in play).  
 - Rs win 0 seats (Ds get all 4). This probability is about 8 percent and this is the only outcome that will give Ds a 51/49 majority.   So, with starting assumptions tilted in favor of the Ds, I only get an 8% chance of Ds winning a majority. This is in stark contrast with the consensus here (and on Predictit), which gives them 33-35%. I am willing to round my number up to 10%, but no more. It will be an amazing achievement for Ds to hold to all 3 vulnerable seats in deeply red states (MO/IN/ND), and turn over the red seat in AZ. Possible, yes, but not very likely. The D Senators in MO/IN/ND are all popular, pragmatic, and attuned to local conditions, but they were helped in 2012 by the high turnout of the D base in the presidential elections, which may not be the case in 2018.

Republicans still favorites to hold the Senate due to a friendly map, but odds of a big majority have fallen.

Historically when the approval polls are against the President they tend to vote the opposition in to the Senate more. The sentiment is against the incumbents too though paradoxically the rate that incumbents are reelected is massive, over 95% in expensive Senate campaigns. A few are retiring, giving the other party a slightly higher chance.

Baseline: Assume that the Rs will lose Nevada and even Arizona, and get two of the Missouri/Indiana/ND seats currently held by Ds (all three D incumbents do not do very well on predictit.org. This keeps 51/49. The tails are based on: (i) Ds holding all 3 of the MO/IN/ND trio, and (ii) Rs keeping AZ and getting all of MO/IN/ND. Of course, this is just a preliminary guesz, more when candidates become clear.

To gain control of the Senate, Democrats will need to pretty much run the table, including in red states where many targeted Democratic incumbents must defend their seats, Much better chance in 2020, when so many Republicans who won in 2014 Republican wave will need to defend their seats, especially if a strong Democratic Presidential ticket and attractive challengers can be found. No enough vulnerable Republicans in 2018 to flip the Senate.

Previously underbudgeted for future time-decay (i.e. absent significant change in contributing factors, over time variance should monotonically decrease).  But of course, recent history suggests there will be surprises.

Current breakdown is 51-49 for the republicans (I'm going to count the two independents as democrats for simplicity). Republicans defend 8 seats while democrats defend 25. I think democrats have 2 good opportunities for pickups (Nevada and Arizona) and two reach opportunities (Tennessee and Texas, although I admit to just hating Tex Cruz). Republicans have 10 chances for pickups (the ten states trump won, depending on candidates). Based on all that and considering the advantages democrats have this year (with three exceptions the presidents party always loses in midterms, enthusiasm gap, etc.), I think we end up with a wash. The disproportionate number of seats up for election favors Repos to retain control.  However, if it looks like the Mueller investigations will implicate Trump then there is a much better chance that Demos will win a majority.

As others have noted, Dems are on the defensive this year regarding competitive seats that are open this year. 23 Dems and 2 Inds are up for reelection, compared to just 8 Reps total (not counting any special elections). The 8 GOP seats are Wyoming, Tennessee, Texas, Nebraska, Arizona, Utah, Nevada, and Mississippi. Maybe the Dems flip Nevada, and if they're really lucky Arizona based on changing demographics and a potential Joe Arpaio GOP nominee. But otherwise these states are hardly purple. On the flip side, the Dems are protecting seats in Wisconsin, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Indiana, New Mexico, North Dakota, Virginia, Minnesota, West Virginia, Missouri, Florida, Minnesota, and Montana, which are red or purple states. Throw Maine into the mix too with Angus King up for reelection. I understand there's a potential wave coming, but these are still potentially challenging seats to protect for the Dems, candidates pending.

Predicting a McSally win in AZ and a Heller loss in Nevada with the possibility of a 50-50 tie giving Reps their majority. This assumes Dems hold on to all of their tossup seats so, hedging due to uncertainty.

The Dem's have 49 seats now.  They are mostly defending seats so that makes it tough to get above 53.  They currently have 47, so 53 seems out of the question.  Could they win as many as 5 more?  Doubtful but possible.   Could Republicans pick up 2?  Possible, but also unlikely.

The large number of seats the Democratic party will have to defend sets the odds in favor of a net gain in Senate seats by the Republicans (I am sure it is a typo but 4th line choice looks like a hybrid party "Remocratic" -  so in a bow to innovation and imagination I am awarding them a 10% chance.  Strong economy and tons more money in the campaign coffers of Republican Senate election committee should offset low popularity of President and Congress.
